Gordon Statement
President Gordon unfortunately avoided a face-toface meeting with the Hopkins community by releasing
a surprisingly short document that at once
best and worst ot the man. The document is good
because it presents ideas for the future of the University
that are, at the least, provocative. Though he only halfheartedly defends the place of the undergraduate in the
University, he does ask for extensive involvement by the
University in the community.
But, as we all hae noted so many times in the past
four years, Gordon seems unable to express himself in a
clear, concise manner, instead cloudiing the issue with
his own brand of diplomatic verbiage.
Perhaps the most significant passage in Gordon's
statement is the one that confirms campus rumors
concerning substantive action on the choice of an interim president. Apparently the Board of Trustees is
making this decision with typical Hopkins secrecy, as
Board members continually refused comment on the
choice. We urge that this matter be opened up immediately and that the University community be informed of the identity of the candidates for the interim
post. If such secrecy is continued throughout the
selection of the permanent president, it will spell
disaster for the future of Hopkins.

Area Majors
One of the problems facing the proponents of revision
in the undergraduate curriculum, as well as those
people concerned with the governance question, is what
to do with area majors. The recent undergraduate
hearings committee report recommended abolishing
the non-departmental majors. Though the move was illadvised, it did draw attention to the problems of the
academic anonymity brought about by the refusal to
specialize.
This problem of intellectual isolation could be solved
by giving each area major its own "department," a
rotating committee composed of professors from the
separate areas. These committees would have departmental status within the university hierarchy. The five
new "departments" would have two official duties-running the advising program for majors within their
area and drawing up the requirements for their majors
in consultation with the Committee on Undergraduate
Studies and the Academic Council.
It is clear that the area majors program should not be
abolished. Now, it is the only way for anyone but an
aspiring professional academician to relate to this
research-oriented University. By giving each area
major its own department, the liberal arts-oriented
undergraduate would be able to enjoy the flexibility this
program embodies while having the personal contact
with faculty members he now lacks. Though the
relationship could never be as close as now exists between individual departments and their mejors, it would
be another step towards making Hopkins a true community.
Moreover, this scheme would aid in solving the
governance question. Last summer's committee
grappled with the role of the area major in a University
that is run almost entirely by autonomous departments,
finally and rather clumsily proposing that each major
attach himself to an individual department for governance questions. Unfortunately, this would result in
students who might have little invested in a department
voting on matters solely of internal importance. By
giving each area a department, it would be possible for
the area majors to exercise governmental input at the
all-important department level, thus clearing the way
for meaningful reforms of the governance system.

You'd think that with all the progress we've made in the education game, somebody would have found a cure for roommates by now.
But no. Roommates remain as big a problem today as they were when
Ethan Mather founded the first American college.
(Incidentally, despite what you've heard, Harvard was not the
first American college. My. Mather started his institution almost 100

motto CAVE MUSS!— "Watch out for moose." The student union
contained four bowling alleys, 21 horoscope machines and a 97-chair
barbershop.
(It was the barbershop, alas, that brought Mr. Mather's college
to an early and total end. The student body, alas, then as now, considered haircuts an Establishment hangup, and nobody set foot in the
barbershop. The chief barber, Truscott Follicle by name, grew so depressed staring at 97 empty chairs that one day his mind finally gave
way. Seizing his vibrator, he ran outside and shook the entire campus

Charge.")

chicken feathers during his prayers at dawn and dusk. What I did
mind was that he singed them in my hat.

Gordon Statement
President Gordon unfortunately avoided a face-toface meeting with the Hopkins community by releasing
a surprisingly short document that at once
best and worst ot the man. The document is good
because it presents ideas for the future of the University
that are, at the least, provocative. Though he only halfheartedly defends the place of the undergraduate in the
University, he does ask for extensive involvement by the
University in the community.
But, as we all hae noted so many times in the past
four years, Gordon seems unable to express himself in a
clear, concise manner, instead cloudiing the issue with
his own brand of diplomatic verbiage.
Perhaps the most significant passage in Gordon's
statement is the one that confirms campus rumors
concerning substantive action on the choice of an interim president. Apparently the Board of Trustees is
making this decision with typical Hopkins secrecy, as
Board members continually refused comment on the
choice. We urge that this matter be opened up immediately and that the University community be informed of the identity of the candidates for the interim
post. If such secrecy is continued throughout the
selection of the permanent president, it will spell
disaster for the future of Hopkins.

Area Majors
One of the problems facing the proponents of revision
in the undergraduate curriculum, as well as those
people concerned with the governance question, is what
to do with area majors. The recent undergraduate
hearings committee report recommended abolishing
the non-departmental majors. Though the move was illadvised, it did draw attention to the problems of the
academic anonymity brought about by the refusal to
specialize.
This problem of intellectual isolation could be solved
by giving each area major its own "department," a
rotating committee composed of professors from the
separate areas. These committees would have departmental status within the university hierarchy. The five
new "departments" would have two official duties-running the advising program for majors within their
area and drawing up the requirements for their majors
in consultation with the Committee on Undergraduate
Studies and the Academic Council.
It is clear that the area majors program should not be
abolished. Now, it is the only way for anyone but an
aspiring professional academician to relate to this
research-oriented University. By giving each area
major its own department, the liberal arts-oriented
undergraduate would be able to enjoy the flexibility this
program embodies while having the personal contact
with faculty members he now lacks. Though the
relationship could never be as close as now exists between individual departments and their mejors, it would
be another step towards making Hopkins a true community.
Moreover, this scheme would aid in solving the
governance question. Last summer's committee
grappled with the role of the area major in a University
that is run almost entirely by autonomous departments,
finally and rather clumsily proposing that each major
attach himself to an individual department for governance questions. Unfortunately, this would result in
students who might have little invested in a department
voting on matters solely of internal importance. By
giving each area a department, it would be possible for
the area majors to exercise governmental input at the
all-important department level, thus clearing the way
for meaningful reforms of the governance system.
